Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Massachusetts Dartmouth (UMass Dartmouth) and its school and community partners are preparing 20 new science and mathematics teachers (Teaching Fellows) and 10 Master Teaching Fellows as STEM educators for the middle and secondary schools of Fall River, New Bedford, and Wareham, MA. The project is preparing STEM teachers by focusing on three major program strands: 1) educators deepening their STEM content knowledge and instructional practices through content-intensive learning experiences; 2) educators developing critical 21st century skills through the active exploration of emerging technologies in STEM education; and 3) educators developing teacher leadership skills via a collaborative approach, based on a proven model that utilizes peer-coaching, mentoring, and professional learning communities. Teaching Fellows earn a Master of Arts in Teaching-Initial licensure in 15 months, an accelerated schedule that includes a full year of teaching residency in a high-need school. Master Teaching Fellows earn a graduate-level 12-credit STEM Teacher Leadership Certificate within one year, developing mentoring skills, and ushering the TFs into the teaching profession. While participating in the program, the Teaching Fellows are developing into master teachers, earning a professional teaching license and a STEM Teacher Leadership Certificate.

Through the training and mentoring activities of the TFs and MTFs, together with the project's in-depth data management and thorough evaluation, the project is uncovering direct relationships between teacher preparation and student achievement. The project is tracking the growth of content knowledge and pedagogical skills in beginning teachers, and also tracking the development of leadership and mentoring skills in experienced teachers. With the requirement that both TFs and MTFs complete coursework in educational research, the participants engage in interpreting and sharing their own research, contributing to change in STEM classrooms. In addition, the program is contributing to the development of a Technology/Engineering teaching license at UMass Dartmouth, meeting an urgent regional need.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The TEACH! SouthCoast STEM grant was a seven-year program that supported math and science teachers for six years. The three goals of this project include: (1) Deepen STEM Content Knowledge and instructional practices through myriad content-intensive learning experiences; (2) Develop Critical 21st Century Skills through the active exploration of emerging technologies in STEM education; and (3) Develop Teacher Leadership Skills via a collaborative approach, based on a proven model that utilizes peer-coaching, mentoring, and professional learning communities.

Our cohort was comprised of 18 teachers from six partner school districts in the culturally and ethnically diverse SouthCoast region of Massachusetts (Fall River Public School, Diman Regional Vocational Technical High School, New Bedford Public School, Global Learning Charter Public School, Greater New Bedford Regional Vocational Technical High School, and Wareham Public School) including 5 Teaching Fellows & 13 Master Teaching Fellows.

In the first two years post-recruitment into the program, participants completed either their Masters of Arts in Teaching and earned an Initial Teaching License (TFs) OR completed the Teacher Leadership program (MTFs). Over the next four years, the fellows have participated in STEM internships, attended & presented at National/Regional STEM conferences, and completed STEM graduate coursework to strengthen their content knowledge. In addition, they have completed professional development to strengthen their technology competencies, content knowledge, and teacher leadership skills. One signature aspect of this program was that the fellows completed an internship (local and/or national) to bring new experiences into their schools and classrooms to share with their colleagues and to engage students in cutting-edge math and science activities. All fellows have earned their Professional Teaching License in Massachusetts, and 10 have earned a second Masters while engaged in the program.

Evidence to support that the grant met the three goals:

Goal 1:  STEM Content

"Our NSF Fellows have a very strong command in content knowledge, but what stands out is the diversity in their instruction to a ray of students in varying abilities and their ability to present continues to improve." -School Administrator

"The Fellows are expanding and creating more innovative ways to teach their content. There is more experimental learning and action learning...generating new excitement for learning in their classroom." -School Administrator

"I have taken a lot more content courses over the past year which directly help my instruction and content knowledge." -Fellow

"Having the opportunity to attend conferences has really served as a useful tool for our department to gain new fresh ideas to bring back to the classroom." -Fellow

"I have worked diligently to create a biotechnology program that includes partial sponsorship from Amgen and I am now working to include zebrafish as a model organism in both my biology and biotechnology classes." -Fellow, referencing internship experience  

Goal 2: Technology

"The students are used to using technology as an interactive tool outside of school, now, because of the program, we are able to bring that idea into the classroom. I'm seeing kids more involved and excited to learn because of the growth in technology."-School Administrator

"The power of technology for the kids is amazing. It's their world. They are comfortable with technology, but have limited understanding of the power of its uses. We are teaching how to utilize the technology and showing value added. We want the kids to be not just consumers of technology, but producers." -School Administrator

"I liked the exposure to a variety of technological resources an that the culminating project was something that we could actually use in our classrooms.  Also, I feel much more comfortable applying for grants." -Fellow

"They've [students] benefited a great in that they're just that much more engaged...They're taking their knowledge and finding ways to connect to the community.  They are creating their own apps to benefit the community.  It's quite amazing. They love it! Technology is really giving them 24-hour hour access to learning.  The technology has helped us personalize the learning process more.  The NSF program has helped us so much we are really grateful for it." -Fellow

Goal 3: Teacher Leadership

"The Fellows are utilizing their new knowledge of technology and sharing it with our other teachers. The other staff is learning from them. They are leading the other teachers into a different realm." -School Administrator

"I felt most energized about being a part of this program during this last semester of leadership classes." -Fellow

"I have used strategies learned at NSTA conferences during meeting with teachers at my schools." -Fellow

"I became a mentor and served on more committees, but I think that in order to really be seen as a teacher leader in a school where the position doesn't really exist, I need to step outside the box and help design/implement new strategies to pilot at the school and work with a range of agencies and resources from outside the school." -Fellow
